Published by Oxford University Press. 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial License ( https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ Abstract Acute lung injury (ALI) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) present significant challenges in critical care, with high mortality rates and limited treatment options. Alveolar epithelial type 2 (AT2) cells are central to lung repair and regeneration and play a vital role in maintaining lung homeostasis. However, the regulatory mechanisms governing AT2 cell fate during different stages of lung injury and repair remain incompletely understood. This review delves into the temporal and spatial heterogeneity of AT2 cells, highlighting their dynamic behavior in response to lung injury. We explore the pivotal role of AT2 cells across various stages of inflammation, repair, and fibrosis and discuss how these processes are influenced by factors such as aging, mechanical stress, and interactions within the alveolar microenvironment. This review also emphasizes the importance of integrating spatiotemporal multiomics approaches to uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying AT2 cell function and their potential therapeutic applications. Furthermore, we discuss novel strategies for enhancing the regenerative capacity of AT2 cells through targeted delivery systems, including protein, gene, and mitochondrial therapies. By advancing our understanding of AT2 cell biology and improving therapeutic approaches, we aim to pave the way for more effective treatments for lung injury diseases, particularly ALI and ARDS. The repair ability of AT2 cells directly affects the prognosis of ALI/ARDS patients [ 6 Review Temporal heterogeneity of AT2 cells The fate and function of AT2 cells are profoundly influenced by temporal factors, particularly in the context of lung injury and repair. These temporal variations are shaped by two primary factors: the different time stages following injury and the age of the individual at the time of injury. The specific timing after injury determines how AT2 cells respond and transition through phases of inflammation, repair, and fibrosis, while the age of the individual introduces additional complexity, as the regenerative capacity of AT2 cells diminishes with age. Together, these factors create a dynamic landscape in which the behavior and regulatory mechanisms of AT2 cells vary significantly over time, underscoring the importance of understanding these temporal dimensions to develop more effective treatments for lung injury and disease. Wnt signaling is critical, with increased Wnt production postinjury driving AT2 cell proliferation through autocrine signaling. Wang et al. reported that the persistence of transitional AT2 cells through a Krt8-dependent mechanism leads to refractory fibrosis by regulating chemokine expression and macrophage recruitment, thereby reinforcing fibrogenesis [ 46 57 58 59 In addition to their roles mentioned above, AT2 cells are crucial for alveolar liquid clearance (ALC) by regulating ENaC and Na-K-ATPase, which mediate sodium transport and fluid removal [ 60 61 The fate of AT2 cells in aging lung Lung tissue repair capacity declines markedly with age, leading to worse outcomes in elderly patients with lung injury, as seen during the COVID-19 pandemic and in animal models where aged mice exhibit higher mortality, greater fibrosis, and impaired alveolar regeneration [ 62–66 67 68 69 70 69 70 71 Figure 2 Figure 2 Intrinsic and extrinsic factors regulating AT2 cell fate in aging lungs. This figure highlights the intrinsic and extrinsic factors that influence AT2 cell fate and repair capacity in aging lungs. Intrinsic factors include telomere dysfunction and metabolic dysregulation. Telomere dysfunction, along with DNA damage, occurs when telomeres uncap, driven by FBW7-mediated degradation of TPP1, leading to cellular senescence. Metabolic dysregulation, particularly inactivation of the AMPKPFKFB2 pathway, impairs glycolysis and promotes the formation of transitional AT2 cells, limiting their ability to differentiate and self-renew. Extrinsic factors include mechanical stress and changes in the alveolar microenvironment. Mechanical stress, caused by ECM remodeling and increased tissue stiffness, disrupts the Cdc42–YAP signaling axis, worsening alveolar remodeling and fibrosis in aging lungs. Additionally, the secretion of growth factors such as Wnt and Pdgfr is reduced in senescent fibroblasts (expressing p16INK4a), and aged immune cells (regulatory T cells and macrophages) further impair the regenerative capacity of AT2 cells. Collectively, these factors contribute to diminished lung repair and increased fibrosis in the aging lung. For example, recent studies have shown that glycogen utilization is crucial in the transformation of fibroblasts into myofibroblasts within fibrotic lung regions [ 136 New strategies and methods to increase the endogenous regenerative capacity of AT2 cells Current therapeutic approaches for ALI and ARDS have shown limited effectiveness, prompting a focus on developing treatments that actively promote lung repair. Given the key role of AT2 cells in this process, they have become central to targeted therapeutic strategies. The primary challenge lies in developing delivery systems that can precisely target the lungs, specifically AT2 cells. Researchers have explored various platforms, including microvesicles [ 137 138 139–141 142 143 144 145 One effective approach is protein delivery systems. For example, Wnt3a has been shown to promote AT2 cell proliferation, which is crucial for lung repair. However, its hydrophobic nature limits its therapeutic application. Researchers have developed a novel approach using extracellular vesicles (EVs) to deliver Wnt3a, maintaining its biological activity and demonstrating significant therapeutic effects in lung injury models. Wnt3a-loaded EVs improved lung function, reduced abnormal alveolar structures, and promoted AT2 cell regeneration. However, the role of Wnt3a in fibroblast proliferation postinjury complicates its use, highlighting the need for selective targeting. This challenge is also relevant to other growth factors, such as EGF and FGF. Consequently, research has focused on protein delivery systems with enhanced specificity for AT2 cells. For example, targeting pathological markers such as CD38 on AT2 cells with engineered mesenchymal stem cell-derived EVs has shown promise in reversing epithelial–mesenchymal transition and reducing age-related pulmonary fibrosis by restoring NAD+ levels in senescent AT2 cells. Gene therapy approaches are also advancing, with mRNA and CRISPR technologies leading the way. The stability and safety of mRNAs, as recognized by the 2023 Nobel Prize, make them a preferred choice [ 146 139 CRISPR-Cas9 technology offers another powerful tool, especially for treating genetic lung diseases through precise gene editing. Viral delivery systems, such as AAV6.2FF, have shown high efficiency in targeting AT2 cells [ 144 145 140 141 141 145 In addition to protein and gene delivery systems, mitochondrial replacement therapy is emerging as a promising strategy, particularly for conditions such as pulmonary fibrosis. By engineering mesenchymal stem cells, researchers have developed methods for efficient mitochondrial transfer, restoring the function of damaged lung cells. ( a b c AT2 MSC CRISPR AAV LNPs BMP4 CYB5R3 CX43 Mito-MEN Parkin mRNA Conclusions In conclusion, AT2 cells are central to lung repair and regeneration and play a pivotal role in addressing ALI and ARDS. Their regenerative capabilities are influenced by spatial heterogeneity and temporal dynamics, yet the mechanisms governing their fate and behavior remain poorly understood. Recent advances in spatiotemporal multiomics and other cutting-edge technologies have significantly expanded our comprehension of AT2 cell fate determination, findings that have been validated across both human and murine model systems. Nevertheless, multiple studies continue to highlight the existence of species-specific differences. Therefore, identifying conserved regulatory mechanisms that drive AT2 cell function and pursuing clinical translation represent the paramount priorities. To improve therapeutic strategies, developing targeted delivery systems is crucial for effectively modulating AT2 cell functions. Approaches such as EVs for protein delivery and gene editing technologies show promise, but challenges in specificity and sustained delivery need to be addressed. Future research should focus on the spatiotemporal regulation of AT2 cells and their interactions with other cell types. By integrating insights from advanced technologies, we can deepen our understanding of lung tissue repair mechanisms. This knowledge is vital for creating personalized therapies for ALI, ARDS, and related lung diseases, ultimately improving patient outcomes and quality of life.
